body.p:
Lexington July 8th 63.
Govr Robinson
Dr Sir,

Mr White of this town became the bail of a man by the name of Robt Thompson, who was indicted in the Fayette Circuit Court for obtaining property under false pretenses. I did not think much of Thompson, thou White I have known for many years. He is a clever gentleman &, in my opinion, went the bail of Thompson, in full faith that he would appear to answer the charge. Thompson professed to be a business man but left as I am informed, with the Rebels, when driven out last fall by Gen Buell. Being in the Confederate lines, it is impossible that White can procure his amnt. I feel satisfied, he would produce him if it were in his power, White is well known to the atty
for the Comm, as is also Thompson, and I presume will agree with me as to the character of the man,

The sum which White will have to pay the Officers, is a severe penalty on him, and a release of the balance of this judgment will, I think, be but justice, as he did not, in my opinion, anticipate the escape of Thompson to parts and probably beyond the reach of our laws, and his inability to arrest & surrender him on his failure to make his appearance.
I fully concur in the truth of the foregoing statements and if your Excellency can, hope you ^will^ grant Mr White a remission
